*Title:* Responsive web design with React, best practices
*Tags:* React, material-ui
*Github link:*
*Description:* Diving into responsive web design with React for the first time. Wondering if my approach is an anti-pattern in any way, since it doesn’t seem super common: for each view in my app, I’m creating a “container” component (e.g. `AppDashboard`) that uses a series of material-ui’s `<Hidden>` component to basically do a switch statement across a bunch of child components that each lay out a different screen size, e.g. `AppDashboardDesktop` vs. `AppDashboardMobile`. I’m separately extracting out all common children-of-children components, strings of text, etc so there’s little code duplication between those two child components. I think this makes it a lot easier to manage the different layouts that end up pieced together with material-ui `<Grid>` components - you don’t mess up the mobile view if you make changes to the desktop view. But it seems the more common approach would be to use just one file, and do e.g. `<Grid sm={8} md={4} xl={3}>`. Is this just the old webdev non-React way of thinking, or am I missing something?

Here are some of the useful resources I found

The tricky part was nailing down the build, login, push, deploy logic in the deploy jobs. This required A) including a setup_remote_docker step to be able to build, B) installing the AWSCLI with sudo so that we can login, which requires ENV variables w/ AWS creds, C) tagging and pushing, D) check if a task in the family is already running. if so, kill it. and run a task with the fresh docker image (tagged as “latest”)

Unfortunately CircleCI (e.g. via Github’s exposed functionality) cannot differentiate between a regular branch and one with a Pull Request. So, we landed on the following logic until the feature requests make their way through.
- Any commit to a branch > Run Tests > Hold for approval (Optional) > Deploy to Staging
- Any commit to master > Run Tests > Hold for approval for either Staging or Production (Optional) > Deploy to Staging or Production

Ideally we would follow this logic:
- Any commit to a branch > Run Tests
- Any commit to a PR’d branch > Run Tests > Deploy to Staging
- Any commit to master / merged branch > Run Tests > Deploy to Staging > Hold for approval > Deploy to production
One area that ended up being a bit tricky was the workflow logic upon successful build.
As you can see, each deploy job follows a similar routine with the major difference being which ECR repository and ECS task definition to use.
<@U8C2LGL7N> uploaded a file: <https://codeclippy.slack.com/files/U8C2LGL7N/F8NSE3C92/config.yml|config.yml>

This was my question! After reading through the latest CircleCI docs and blog posts, I landed on a solution that uses two jobs and one workflow. The jobs contain the relevant bash commands for building, logging into ECR, tagging and pushing the image, and running the task on ECS. Uploading the config.yml here.

figured it out: appears that `tmpdir_factory` doesn't wipe the tmpdir (from previous runs) until it is invoked. this only became a problem in my unorthodox use of tmpdir: i've overridden the dir with the `--basetemp=pytest-tmp` cli option, and i'm hardcoding the presence of an in-file database (during tests) in my app setup in that same directory

```
@pytest.fixture(scope='session')
def test_router(test_slack_client_factory, test_send_grid_client, test_twilio_client, test_solutionloft_client,
                test_bot_client, tmpdir_factory):
    database_wrapper = DatabaseClientWrapper()
    return Router(
        bot=Bot(
            bot_client=test_bot_client,
            bot_id=0,
            admin_user_ids=[0],
            admin_group_id=None,
            help_channel_id=None,
            slack_client=test_slack_client_factory,
            database_wrapper=database_wrapper,
            log_file=f'{tmpdir_factory.getbasetemp()}/bot.log'
        ),
        slack_client=test_slack_client_factory,
        sendgrid_client=SendGridClientWrapper(test_send_grid_client, f'{tmpdir_factory.getbasetemp()}/sendgrid.log'),
        twilio_client=TwilioClientWrapper(test_twilio_client, f'{tmpdir_factory.getbasetemp()}/twilio.log'),
        solutionloft_client=SolutionLoftClientWrapper(test_solutionloft_client, f'{tmpdir_factory.getbasetemp()}/solutionloft.log'),
        database_wrapper=database_wrapper,

The only reason I'm saying you probably don't want a PK at all is that my impression is that you're scrapping this together for some one-off type of data analysis, but if you're building some kind of system that needs to maintain data integrity over time (i.e. dozens of experiments & hundreds of thousands of rows over months of time), then you probably do want that `(experiment_id, time_from_start)` PK along with a critical eye towards your data model (i.e. evaluate whether or not your spreadsheet format with its current layout of sheets and columns actually makes sense to represent your data)
That is if I'm understanding this correctly and that each experiment has 1 row of data per 1 second of runtime

Correct, you would not want experiment_id to be a PK -- in your case i don't think you would have a PK at all to keep it simple. A PK (whether it is one column or a composite of multiple columns) represents a piece of data by which you can uniquely identify an instance (row) of the concept (the object represented by the table). So if you *really* want a PK then it'd probably be a composite PK of `(experiment_id, time_from_start)`

Actually something with `flask-restful` is complicating the error handling
But that’s the current fix while other aspects are higher priority
My gut is that a different error approach may be needed for blueprints, etc. As it doesn’t make sense to have to change that flag to handle custom errors.
Otherwise they don’t get propagated and will error out with 500
By explicitly enabling it, the application errors will be caught by the handlers
After looking into it, the key configuration setting was `PROPAGATE_EXCEPTIONS`
Originally it was resolved by setting `TESTING=true`, which changes a number of builtin configuration values just as setting `DEBUG=true` does.
Or did you end up resolving this issue just via the `TESTING=True` flag?

I wonder if it had something to do with Flask's handling of contexts (application context & request context) -- not sure exactly how registering application error handlers work under the hood, but wouldn't be surprised if they're bound to the application context, and then something like this bit
```
<http://flask.pocoo.org/docs/0.12/appcontext/>

Locality of the Context¶
The application context is *created and destroyed as necessary. It never moves between threads* and it will not be shared between requests. As such it is the perfect place to store database connection information and other things. The internal stack object is called flask._app_ctx_stack. Extensions are free to store additional information on the topmost level, assuming they pick a sufficiently unique name and should put their information there, instead of on the flask.g object which is reserved for user code.
```
results in that handling not carrying over

For using a class - most libraries out there do that so modularity, separation of concerns, etc is clear to someone using the functionality. Most importantly it enables you to avoid repetitive code in examples like my note about storing the `token`. Another example would be if you want to point to different URL's in a development environment versus a production environment. 4) Re: your question about exceptions. It's generally not good practice to use the bare `Exception` class. You could either find something descriptive from the list of built-in exceptions (<https://docs.python.org/3/library/exceptions.html#exception-hierarchy>), but in your case I don't think anything fits, so it'd be useful to implement your own e.g. `GitHubWrapperException` or if you want to be more specific `UnauthorizedException` and `NotFoundException` etc

The reason for not using `Exception` is because it's not descriptive and might obscure unexpected issues. For example, if you raise `Exception` in your code, and someone wants to use your code, and they want to do `try: ... except Exception: ...` because they want to do something if GitHub returns a 404, that could end poorly for them because what if there's some completely different Exception raised e.g. a `KeyError`, which their `try/except` would capture as well

3) Re: your first question about class/module. Yes, it would make sense to put this in a class. You'd want to do something like this:
```
def request_decorator(request):
  ...

class GitHubWrapper:
  BASE_GITHUB_API_URL = '<https://api.github.com>'

  @request_decorator
  def get_organization_repos(login, kind, access_token=None):
    ...
```
and then you could call it like this
```
  git_hub_wrapper = GitHubWrapper()
  git_hub_wrapper.get_organization_repos(login=my_login, kind=my_kind)
```
and so on. You could take it a step further by adding an `__init__` that takes an access token, and then you would be able to do something like:
```
git_hub_wrapper = GitHubWrapper(token=my_token)
git_hub_wrapper.get_organization_repos(login=my_login, kind=my_kind)
```
and all your calls with that wrapper would be authenticated

2) If you're using python3 (if you're not, you should upgrade! :slightly_smiling_face:), the new string formatting syntax is a lot cleaner. e.g. `f'{BASE_GITHUB_API_URL}/repos/{login}/{repo_name}/commits?sha={branch_name}'`

But even if they do throw 403, it would probably be best practice to _not_ swallow the error and raise some exception instead
